John Lewis was a true American hero and the moral compass of our nation. May his courage and conviction live on in all of us as we continue to make good trouble for justice and opportunity.
 
Rest in power, John.

We mourn the loss of @RepJohnLewis, one of our nation’s most extraordinary civil rights leaders and the conscience of Congress. His passing is a huge and heartbreaking loss for our country.

Rest in power.

He would send shivers up and down my spine when he urged us to engage in “good trouble.“ We owe him to pursue good trouble in his name. It is not negotiable.

We must all carry on his legacy of engaging in “Good Trouble” when we witness injustice and continue the fight for equality for all.  His family, loved ones and his staff are in Janet and my prayers as we collectively mourning this tremendous loss to our nation.” http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EdLvW_7XoAAM0L0.jpg

Today our country lost a great American and magnificent man, John Lewis. One of my greatest honors in Congress has been serving on the Ways and Means Committee with this civil rights icon who put his own well-being at risk to fight for freedom for all Americans.
He was a simple man with a simple purpose -human rights for all people and it was not negotiable. His riveting oratory forced all of us to stop what we were doing and listen.

We have lost a great human being, civil rights hero, mentor, friend, and role model. We will miss you terribly. Rest In Power, my friend! http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EdLvKULWsAIpVFv.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EdLvKULX0AEy6v4.jpg

RT @RepScottPeters My thoughts are with Congressman John Lewis' family and loved ones tonight. Rep. John Lewis changed the course of our history through his brave activism for civil rights alongside MLK Jr. and continued his unwavering dedication to justice for all in the halls of Congress.

John Lewis called on us to find “good trouble.”  

And so we must until we at last build a nation as good as John was.

Those of us lucky enough to serve with John Lewis and to travel with him to Selma will never forget his unquenchable passion for building a beloved community and an America worthy of our most sacred values. 

He was a legend, a humble giant and a towering American. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EdLt5RtWkAE95YM.jpg

John touched my life in more ways than I can imagine.  He touched our nation in more ways than we can know. From his early civil rights work in the 1960s to his 33 years as a member of Congress, John Lewis cast a giant shadow for good.
In Selma, Alabama, John Lewis laid down his life on the Edmund Pettus Bridge for a faith that our shared country could be something greater.

John Lewis was true greatness. 

He was so much more than an inspiration to his colleagues.  He was our moral compass, the conscious of the House.  When he spoke, everyone would listen.  Where he would lead, all were ready to follow.
Today the world lost a giant in John Lewis.  Our country is so much better because of his life and his work.  Every one among us is blessed for having known him and walking with him.

RT @TheBlackCaucus We will keep our eye on the prize of social justice, voting rights, quality education, affordable health care, and economic empowerment for every soul. The entire Congressional Black Caucus extends our condolences to Mr. Lewis’ family, friends, staff, and the city of Atlanta.
RT @TheBlackCaucus spark a modern-day civil rights movement against police brutality and racial injustice. He taught us to keep our eye on the prize, and that lesson is more crucial than ever.

RT @TheBlackCaucus Despite more than 40 arrests, brutal attacks, and physical injuries, Mr. Lewis remained devoted to the philosophy of nonviolence in his fight for justice and equality, even to this day, as America faces another reckoning with racism and hundreds of thousands around the world
RT @TheBlackCaucus His mere presence encouraged a new generation of activist to “speak up and speak out” and get into “good trouble” to continue bending the arc toward justice and freedom.

Former FBI Acting Director Andrew McCabe expanded the investigation to include the President, and former Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein appointed Robert Mueller as special counsel.

Mr. Strzok wrote an internal FBI analysis highlighting the story’s numerous inaccuracies, explaining “we are unaware of ANY Trump advisors engaging in conversations with Russian intelligence officials.”
Friday’s disclosure also includes a February 2017 document in which leading FBI investigator Peter Strzok acknowledges the dossier is a bust, and that the FBI still had no evidence of any wrongdoing.

The FBI didn’t corroborate the Steele's claims prior to its first application to surveil Mr. Page in October 2016, and it didn’t interview the source until nearly four months later.  It was then that the source made clear that there was no factual basis to the dossier’s claims.

Former British spy Christopher Steele, whose dirt-digging was financed by the Hillary Clinton campaign, based nearly all of his dossier allegations on information from one unidentified “primary subsource.”

The latest evidence comes from Friday’s declassification via the Senate Judiciary Committee of the FBI’s interviews, over three days in January 2017, with the primary source for the infamous Steele dossier.

Anyone who has been able to hear John Lewis’s voice, see his smile, listen to his laugh, draw from his courage, or even simply know his name, knows that we will never be the same without him walking among us.
And beyond any doubt, that’s exactly what he did during his time on this earth. Not just for Black Americans, but for all who believed that none of us will be free until we are all free.

Today our nation lost a giant. John Lewis didn’t just change this country, he changed the world. RT @HouseAgDems Rest In Peace Congressman Lewis. Thank you for showing us how to make good trouble to change our country for the better.
I will miss you, John, each and every day when I come to the floor of the House. Goodbye my dear brother.

After many mass shootings and the Republicans refused to deal with gun safety bills, John led the Democratic caucus in “good trouble“ as we took over the floor of the House and occupied it for over 24 hours- the highlight of my tenure in Congress.

I was so honored to serve with him. I looked forward and always felt better after seeing him, saying hello, and talking to him about the news of the day. He always took time for all us. In a roudy, noisy House, when John spoke there was complete silence.
John Lewis was a hero, who embodied the best of our country. He leaves a legacy that every American should fight tirelessly to fulfil. We will miss his voice, his courage, and his leadership.

June was the worst month yet for permanent job losses — 2.9 million workers now consider themselves permanently out of work.
We’ve had 15 straight weeks of more than a million unemployment claims — higher than any week during the Great Recession.
It didn’t have to be this bad. Trump is responsible for the highest unemployment since the Great Depression.
Not yet reflected in these numbers are the American workers being laid off a second time because Trump’s failed leadership forced nearly two dozen states to pause or reverse reopening plans.
Nearly 3 million fewer Black Americans and almost 4 million fewer Hispanic Americans were employed last month than in February.
Unemployment is even worse for people of color. More than 15% of Black Americans, more than 14% of Hispanic Americans, and nearly 14% of Asian Americans are out of work.
17.8 million Americans — nearly one in nine workers — are out of work, and another 2.2 million workers filed for some form of unemployment in the fourth week of June.

It’s hard to capture the expanse of his legacy, his ability to unite, and the depth of his impact. From Selma to Washington, Congressman Lewis possessed a quiet power that could move mountains, and that’s exactly what he did.

The day I was sworn in, he hugged both of my kids, bringing tears to my eyes. John Lewis was a national treasure — a combination of brilliance and kindness, patriotism and leadership that is far too rare these days.

I’ll never forget when John traveled to Hackensack to help our campaign. I tried to explain to my young daughter just what this meant — one of the icons responsible for advancing civil rights in America joining us in North Jersey.

It’s not often in life that you have the opportunity to work, side-by-side, with one of your heroes. That’s what serving with Congressman John Lewis was to me — the chance to befriend and glean wisdom from a living legend. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EdP1rjLWkAECy-R.jpg
